text:
(1)
North Baptist Church, 232-6 West 11th Street, and adjoining houses, south side, between Waverly Place and 4th Street. This view shows the doorway of 240 West 11th Street and part of St. John's
Church, which is on the corner at waverly Place.
The North Baptist Church was organized in 1827, at which time it actually was the northermost church of the denomination in Manhattan. This edifice was erected in 1882; the first church building had been at Christopher and Bedford Streets.
May 4, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, a closer view, five years later.
August 6, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Nearly the same view as (1), but six years later. Notice that 238 and 240 West 11th Street have both been remodelled a little. Notice the doorway of 240, at the extreme right of the picture, and the new north light studio on the top floor of 238, as well
es its windows.
May 20, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Church of St. John the Evangelist (Protestant Episcopal), at S.W. corner of 11th Street (formerly Hammond Street) and Waverly
Place, also showing the southeast corner.
This congregation was organized July 26, 1845, and opened its church for services in May, 1856. The church is notable for its garden, the creation of the late Dr. John Armstrong Wade, former pastor, and for the outdoor marriage altar which he brought over
from Spain around 1925.
August 6, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Church of St. John the Evangelist (Protestant Episcopal), at S.W. corner of 11th Street (formerly Hammond Street) and Waverly
Place, also showing the southeast corner.

(1)

11th Street, south side, west from and includine Waverly Place, to and including West 4th Street. Also shown is Waverly Place, west side, south from and including West 11th, to but not including Perry Streets. Building shown (No. 220 West 11th Street) at the S.W. corner of Waverly Place is the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist, with an annex adjoining it on the Waverly Place side. The North Baptist
Church is further down the block (Nos. 236-228).
About 1930.

11th Street (formerly Hammond Street), east on south side from and including the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist on the S.W. corner of Waverly Place, with St. Vincent's Hospital at 1 Seventh Avenue in the background. This church was opened for
services in May, 1856.
May 20, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

11th Street (formerly Hammond Street), south side, from Waverly Place to Seventh and Greenwich Avenues (Mulry Square). Hammond Street met the western end of the true 11th Street at that point, which was the southern end of Seventh Avenue; around 1870 it lost its own name and was remembered as part of 11th Street.

214-09, the four brownstone-front houses shown here, are all that was left of the block on 11th Street from Waverly Place to Greenwich Avenue after Seventh Avenue South was cut through (about 1915), at the time of the construction of the Interborough West Side subway line. The old Continental Brewery, which stood on the S.W. corner of Greenwich Avenue and 11th Street, directly in the way of the subway, was demolished, and later the little one-story building, for shops, was erected to fill in the space along the new Seventh Avenue South. This picture was taken the year Prohibition was repealed; the following year the 11th Street shops shown here were taken over by a liquor store.

May 20, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

239-245 Waverly Place, east side, from and including 11th to Bank Streets. The view also shows 215-209 11th Street, at, adjoining. and east of the N.E. corner of Waverly Place. The Noyes School of
Rhythm occupies the white corner building.
May 10, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

210-212 West 11th Street, adjoining S.E. corner of Waverly Place.
About 1915.
